subject: Gardening

description: Learn Hadrian's Villa Gardens in one minute.

buildup.text: Hadrian's Villa in Tivoli covers 250 acres with gardens replicating Egyptian canals, Greek academies, and more.

discovery.text: The Canopusâ€”a long pool flanked by columns and statuesâ€”recreated an Egyptian canal he visited near Alexandria.

twist.text: The villa was Hadrian's personal memory palace. Each garden section preserved a place he loved but couldn't revisit.

climax.text: Hadrian turned landscape design into autobiography. His garden was a map of everywhere he'd been.

punchline.text: One emperor's garden contained the whole world.

quiz.question: Why did Hadrian build garden replicas of places he had visited?
options: To impress foreign diplomats with his knowledge of their cultures
To preserve memories of places he loved but couldn't revisit
To demonstrate Rome's superiority over conquered civilizations
